paragraphs.text: If we assume an exit distribution where over 60% of a fund’s investments are 0–2x their money, with the remainder falling somewhere between 2–5x, a “unicorn” type 10x+ outcome can put a venture fund into the desired 3x fund returns that puts them among the top performers in VC. Your 1–3 investments that “return the fund” and probably even more (the grand slam), is what will make or break you, while the other 2x-5x investments create additional alpha.
paragraphs.name: 5f8e

paragraphs.text: You can take it a step further and assume that a $50M fund will most likely not be able to fill their pro-rata across every subsequent round, thus their position could get diluted (we’ll leave out the possibility of raising SPVs for pro-rata). If we assume 20% dilution over the lifetime of the investment, then the real return the fund number is $625M ($50M/.08).

cc37df0ff48b.title: Great simple write-up of the RTF theory, thanks!

paragraphs.text: Great simple write-up of the RTF theory, thanks! I have the same question as C Gallo below — how do we explain the startups that don’t make more than 10X? Are they failed opportunities at a grand slam, or “filler” investments for guaranteed mid-rate returns?
paragraphs.name: eed8

87b6d5830a79.title: 20% dilution after seed seems very optimistic.

paragraphs.text: 20% dilution after seed seems very optimistic. In addition to subsequent rounds, a successful company will need to refresh its option pool for new employees.
paragraphs.name: e761

cb0e843a49a2.title: Not too many pure seed funds, but a fair amount of seed + Series A funds fall between $125-$250M.

paragraphs.text: Not too many pure seed funds, but a fair amount of seed + Series A funds fall between $125-$250M.

1c1f8c6ca677.title: So how/why does a VC choose that 60% of low return investments?

paragraphs.text: So how/why does a VC choose that 60% of low return investments? Are these investments that were supposed to be grand slams, or are they low risk investments that were chosen for stability?
(Please forgive me if this is a dumby q)
paragraphs.name: ec35

3c2ff0c50a96.title: Most vc firms today pretend to take the risk which yields returns like the ones in the return bar…

paragraphs.text: Most vc firms today pretend to take the risk which yields returns like the ones in the return bar chart. Vast majority (including so called “accelerators”) try to do growth, and any “risk” investments are all because I’m scratching your back cuz you gave me at least 4x exit.
paragraphs.name: fbe7

2f909aba2934.title: It sort of makes you wonder why the VCs are really in the business.

paragraphs.text: It sort of makes you wonder why the VCs are really in the business. It also makes you wonder what they see when we see ventures getting funding and we are struggling to get a meeting. Do we really need the 10th version of Uber? With so few, as a percentage, hitting Unicorn, it makes the game of doubles and triples more attractive.
paragraphs.name: 6e23

32f8ae3d3235.title: Definitely is optimistic but if you’re a $50M fund you are most likely reserving capital to at…

paragraphs.text: Definitely is optimistic but if you’re a $50M fund you are most likely reserving capital to at least keep your pro-rata through a Series A/B round and then taking dilution after that.
paragraphs.name: 123d

f8245d446776.title: Isn’t this based on the assumption that each investment needs to return the entire fund for it to…

paragraphs.text: Isn’t this based on the assumption that each investment needs to return the entire fund for it to be viable? Which mightn’t be true as exits from all positions combined would give the fund the return.
paragraphs.name: a4bd

2fa9bb8d2b8.title: This assumption is pretty much how venture funds operate.

paragraphs.text: This assumption is pretty much how venture funds operate. With the failure rates of startups, it isn’t realistic to try and have a high batting average across many investments vs. hitting big on a few. Can read more about this in Chris Dixon’s post http://cdixon.org/2015/06/07/the-babe-ruth-effect-in-venture-capital/
paragraphs.name: dd51

5139a666218a.title: The return thinking applies to ‘classic’ VC but to be clear late stage growth investors do not…

paragraphs.text: The return thinking applies to ‘classic’ VC but to be clear late stage growth investors do not think in RTF terms at all. Many companies are better off raising smaller $ skipping classic VC and in time doing a recap to get partial liquidity. A much easier ride for the vast majority of v good but not exceptional companies no?
paragraphs.name: 7e17

1a20bcf83f78.title: How do you handle it when the opportunity scope for returns is so staggering that most investors…

paragraphs.text: How do you handle it when the opportunity scope for returns is so staggering that most investors accessible through your network get intimidated and shut down?
paragraphs.name: 30f0
